Elliotte Harold wrote:

>It might help, but as with some other suggestions on this thread, I'd 
>consider it more seriously if I'd once actually encountered a project 
>that did it. It seems to me that techniques that so obscure they're only 
>known to the cognoscenti indicate there's something missing somewhere.
>  
>
Well, there's the one I was learning yesterday: XMLBeans from the Apache 
project. There's newer versions of Weblogic (the old ones had the 
kitchen-sink JAR from hell). The xml-apis.jar and xercesImpl.jar from 
the Xerces project. The way Ant 1.6 has the optional jars split up. 
Jaxen. Every JDBC driver I've ever used. Hibernate.

And those are just the ones on my home machine.

And if it's an obscure solution, which would actually work, why not 
promote it more? We're discussing the code _you_ can write, which _you_ 
can control - if you want to have a runtime and API jar, only you are 
stopping you.

Also, note the list. It's discussing the JUnit framework. Now, this may 
be shocking to you... but the majority of developers still do not write 
unit tests. I still come across Java developers, some with considerable 
experience, who haven't heard of JUnit. There is no technique so widely 
known that there aren't droves of developers who don't know about it.

>>You keep missing the distinction between "public" and "published":
>>"published" is a social convention enforced by social contracts.
>>Providing a runtime JAR, to be available at _runtime_, and not
>>_compile time_, is an excellent way of enforcing these conventions.
>>    
>>
>
>I've already argued this one to death in this thread; and don't have 
>anything more to add at this point; but I will try to rephrase. There 
>may be a distinction between public and published in the original 
>developer's mind, but it starts and stops there. For the client 
>programmer, public == published; and wishing otherwise ain't going to 
>make it so. The distinction that exists in Java is between public and 
>package-private. That's what you need to work with. Perhaps other 
>languages have clearer distinctions between public and published, but 
>Java doesn't.
>  
>
Except that if you package the published classes seperately, and only 
provide Javadoc for the published classes, then people are not going to 
"stumble over" the non-published classes. We've argued that point to 
death as well.

I don't see it as the duty of an API designer to protect people who 
deliberately go out of their way to inflict pain and suffering on 
themselves. Making a clear distinction to the client programmer is all 
that's called for.

>>Similarly, excluding packages from JavaDoc works well.
>>    
>>
>
>That helps. Unlike runtime/API separation I've actually seen this done. 
>I'd estimate I've seen it about as frequently as I've seen API docs that 
>include package-private and private methods.  It would help more, if it 
>were more common. For instance, why are the junit.samples and 
>junit.tests packages published in the JavaDoc on the JUnit web site at 
>http://www.junit.org/junit/javadoc/3.8.1/index.htm ?
>  
>
I don't know - ask the ObjectMentor folks who set junit.org up. 
However... if you _download_ JUnit 3.8.1, and look at the _distributed_ 
Javadoc, the only packages covered are junit.framework and junit.extensions.

Robert.
